Instrument.name: Aerosol Collector Pyrolyser for Huygens Probe
Instrument.description: The Aerosol Collector Pyrolyser (ACP) on the Huygens Probe was designed to collect aerosols in Titan's atmosphere for chemical composition analysis using filters. Those particles, collected at different altitudes, were heated through the pyrolysis process, which vaporized volatiles and separated complex organic materials. The physical dimensions of the ACP are 220 x 200 x 206 mm. ACP's primary objectives were to: (1) determine the chemical composition of the photochemical aerosol; (2) ascertain the relative abundances of condensed organics in a column average in the lower stratosphere; and, (3) obtain the relative abundances of condensed organics in a column average in the upper troposphere. ACP, in coordination with other probe instruments, also achieved several secondary objectives. In order to achieve these objectives, the instrument was equipped with a deployable sampling device which operated twice during descent in order to collect aerosols. The first sample was taken from 135 km down to about 32 km, while the second sample was taken from about 22 km down to 17 km.
